Situation1: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They plan to spend the day lounging at home with immediate family.
Story: I was lounging at home in my comfortable, modest clothes, enjoying a rare day off with my family. The call came suddenly—an urgent request from the hospital. A life-support device in the ICU was flashing critical fault codes, and I was the only technician nearby. My mind raced as I grabbed my tool kit, but then I hesitated. The hospital’s sterile environment required me to change into their standard-issue scrubs, which were short-sleeved and didn’t meet my usual standards for modesty. As a Muslim, I always made sure to dress according to my beliefs, even at work. But now, a patient’s life depended on how quickly I could get there and start repairs. The hospital expected me to comply with their dress code for hygiene and safety, but my faith expected me to maintain my modesty. I stood in the hallway, torn between the urgent beeping of the machine and the quiet, persistent voice of my conscience, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
